artist: Artist: Kazimir Malevich; Artist: Ol'ga Rozanova; Author: Alexei Kruchenykh; Publisher: Svet, St. Petersburg
catalogue_raissonne: Compton 48, 49, 73; Karshan 3, 4;  Hellyer 255; Ex-Libris 128; MoMA, The Russian Avant-Garde Book, p. 75
creditline: Gift of funds from the Print and Drawing Council and The Christina N. and Swan J. Turnblad Memorial Fund
description: Bound book with three lithographs (two by Malevich, one by Rozanova) in black on cream wove paper and one halftone reproductive print in black on blue-green wove paper (discolored to buff); binding: cream wove paper printed wrappers with letterpress typographical design printed in black on front cover.
medium: Lithographs, photolithographic illustrations, letterpress; bound volume
text:
Vozropshchem (Let's grumble) is a collection of zaum poetry, drama, and prose, incorporating Futurist statements and concluding with a paragraph promoting the Moscow Futurists (Hylaeans), while dismissing the Italian Futurists-the poet and theorist Filippo Tommaso Marinetti and the painters Umberto Boccioni, Carlo Carra, and Gino Severini.

Kruchenykh's text was written in the experimental poetic language zaum, meaning beyond the mind and logic. This language was composed of neologisms, puns, and free associations of sounds and images that removed from words all predictable meaning and instead attempted to directly communicate the internal state of the author.

The book contains three original lithographs, two by Malevich and one by Ol'ga Rozanova, which are awkwardly inserted at the beginning of the book, bear no relationship to the text, and are disproportionate to the book's scale and format.
title: Vozropshchem (Let's grumble)
